Project Description  The  Project  is  to  (i)  rehabilitate  seven  regional  airports  in 
Bamyan,  Chaghcharan,  Faizabad,  Farah,  Maimana,  Qalai-
Naw, and Zaranj; (ii) provide a human resource development 
program to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Civil 
Aviation  and  Tourism;  (iii)  provide  assistance  to 
postconstruction operations following the completion of airport 
rehabilitation; (iv) provide administrative support to set up and 
operate  the  project  steering  committee  and  the  project 
implementation unit; and (v) engage a project management 
consultant. 
  
Rationale  The prolonged state of conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in 
large-scale deterioration of the civil aviation infrastructure and 
a  depletion  of  skilled  personnel.  In  addition  to  the  lack  of 
maintenance, the deterioration was further accelerated by the 
heavy damage inflicted by prolonged civil strife and military 
operations. Afghanistan relies significantly on the civil aviation 
sector  for  keeping  most  of  its  remote  communities  within 
reach  of  much  needed  humanitarian  aid  and  basic  public 
services.  Rehabilitating  and  strengthening  the  civil  aviation 
sector is crucial for extending the reach of the Government in 
Kabul, thereby facilitating stabilization and integration of the 
country. Rehabilitation of the civil aviation infrastructure is a 
prerequisite  for  private  sector  service  providers  to  provide 
efficient  and  affordable  means  of  transport  to  most  of  the 
population living in remote rural provinces. The rehabilitation 
of  the  airports  will  also  help  create  employment,  generate 
income at the household level, improve safety, improve the 
spread  of  medical  facilities,  help  reconcile  different  ethnic 
groups,  and  unify  the  country  politically.  To  the  extent 
possible,  the  Project  will  use  labor-intensive  construction 
methods to provide badly needed employment and income 
generation opportunities.  It  will contribute  to social  stability 
and poverty reduction by engaging those internally displaced 
because of the war and civil unrest. Thus this investment will 
contribute significantly to improving the overall socioeconomic 
situation and mitigating the pervasive poverty.

iv       
In  the  civil  aviation  sector,  the  Government’s  goal  is  to 
rehabilitate and improve airports and air transport, together 
with tourism services. This will bring remote areas into the 
mainstream economy and improve linkages with and faster 
travel to and from the rest of the world and within the country 
between  major  cities  and  towns.  It  will  also  facilitate  the 
movement  of  people,  including  tourists,  for  whom 
Afghanistan’s natural and historical sites should become an 
increasingly attractive destination, and increase trade in low-
volume, high-value goods. With this sectoral goal in place, the 
Government’s key priorities for investment in civil aviation are 
(i)  upgrading  Kabul  International  Airport  to  a  fully  fledged 
international  airport  that  meets  International  Civil  Aviation 
Organization standards; (ii) upgrading Herat, Mazar-e-Sharif, 
and  Jalalabad  airports  to  international  standards;  (iii) 
upgrading 15 other major domestic airports; (iv) establishing 
an  appropriate  air  traffic  management  system  that  meets 
international standards; (v) constructing hangars and parking 
bays; and (vi) building training and other related facilities.  
 
To support the achievement of the Government’s goal in the 
civil aviation sector, aid agencies coordinated their efforts to 
avoid a duplication of assistance and agreed that the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  assistance  for 
rehabilitating domestic and regional airports while the World 
Bank  and  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  will 
support  the  upgrading  of  Kabul  International  Airport. 
Accordingly, ADB’s Country Strategy and Program Update for 
Afghanistan (2003–2005) indicated that ADB assistance in the 
civil aviation sector would be directed toward the rehabilitation 
of important regional airports to promote the integration of 
remote regions and facilitate more rapid economic growth in 
those areas. The Country Strategy and Program Update for 
Afghanistan  (2004–2006)  includes  the  Regional  Airports 
Rehabilitation Project Phase 1 for 2004 in the amount of $30 
million and the Regional Airports Rehabilitation Project Phase 
2 for 2006 in the amount of $40 million.  
 
Objective  The  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  help  the  Government 
reconstruct  and  rehabilitate  the  country  by  rehabilitating 
regional airports damaged during two decades of conflict and 
neglect.

construction. The foreign exchange cost is estimated at $23.7

Implementation 
Arrangements  The Project will be implemented by a project implementation 
unit (PIU) headed by the deputy minister of MCAT as project 
director.  The  PIU  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day 
implementation  of  the  Project,  including  the  completion  of 
training  programs  and  provision  of  assistance  to 
postconstruction operations. The PIU will consist of a team of 
project  management  consultants  who  will  undertake  key 
project management functions and supervise and train MCAT 
staff  assigned  to  the  unit.  A  project  steering  committee, 
chaired by the minister of MCAT and consisting of the deputy 
minister of the Ministry of Finance and the deputy minister of 
MCAT, will be established to provide the overall guidance and 
oversight required for smooth implementation of the Project.  
 
Procurement  The procurement of goods, services, and civil works to be 
financed under the Project will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Given the emergency 
nature  of  the  Project,  the  Government  requested  flexible 
application  of  such  guidelines,  including  a  shorter  bidding 
period for international procurement and no prequalification 
exercise. The Government Procurement Unit of Afghanistan 
Reconstruction  and  Development  Services  (ARDS)  will 
undertake  all  international  procurement,  including  the 
recruitment  of  project  management  consultants.  MCAT  will

execute  and  administer  the  contracts  in  close  coordination

Consulting Services  Consulting services will be required to help MCAT implement 
the Project. The consulting services will involve (i) carrying out 
overall project management as part of the work of the PIU, (ii) 
providing assistance with the procurement of civil works, (iii) 
supervising the construction and installation of equipment, (iv) 
testing and certifying completed works, (v) implementing and

Project Benefits  
and Beneficiaries  The primary economic benefits of the Project consist of (i)  
benefits to operators (direct wear and tear, fuel savings, and 
safety  benefits);  (ii)  benefits  to  passengers  (direct  time 
savings and safety benefits); (iii) benefits to the Government 
(direct  revenue  benefits);  and  (iv)  benefits  to  regional  and 
local  communities  (indirect  tourist  arrival  benefits).  The 
benefits to operators are substantial in terms of improvements 
to  aircraft  productivity  resulting from  reduced  downtime  for 
maintenance; elimination of costs associated with damage to 
aircraft  caused  by  flying  stones  from  gravel  runways  (to 
external instruments, wing flaps, propeller blades, engines); 
and  lowered  tire  replacement  costs  by  extending  the 
operational life of tires. The Project will severely diminish the 
risk (and economic costs) of accidents or incidents. Currently 
airstrip incursions are increasingly becoming a safety hazard 
because of poor regional airstrip conditions and poor visibility. 
 
  Passengers  benefit  from  improved  arrival  and  departure 
reliability,  savings  on  travel  time,  diminished  risks  of  flight 
cancellation  or  diversion,  and  safety  improvements.  The 
current conditions of uncontrolled airstrips, poor visibility, and 
poor  record  of  on  time  arrivals  and  departures  have  a 
significant impact on the confidence of current and potential 
travelers. The current upward trend in airstrip incursions is 
likely to result in a catostrophic accident if airstrips are not 
fenced and properly surfaced and if access  is not controlled. 
 
  At the regional and local community levels, the economy can 
benefit from significant second-round benefits from tourism.

Airports will receive foreign and national tourist traffic because 
some areas have significant potential for attracting tourists.  
  
Risks and Assumptions  Implementation of the Project entails a number of risks. First. 
the  overall  political  and  security  situation  remains  volatile. 
ADB will need to monitor the situation closely and coordinate 
with local and central authorities and the United Nations to 
ensure  adequate  protection  of  ADB  operations.  ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  for  the  Security  of  ADB-Financed 
Projects  in  Afghanistan  will  help  provide  a  safe  work 
environment  for  on-site  personnel  assigned  by  the 
contractors,  subcontractors,  and  consulting  firms.  Given 
prevailing  conditions,  however,  this  security  risk cannot be 
mitigated completely, and if security hazards occur in project 
locations, delays in project implementation will be inevitable 
despite any measures put in place to control this risk. Second, 
the regional warlords maintain their military strength and their 
influence  in  regional  politics.  This  political  instability  could 
hamper the smooth supply of raw materials and equipment, 
which would need to be transported through areas controlled 
by  regional  warlords,  and  constrain  the  supervision  of 
construction works by consultants and ADB staff. Third, the 
rehabilitated  regional  airports  could  be  used  to  transport 
opium.  While  security  checks  in  regional  airports  will  be 
strengthened,  the  distribution  of  opium  through  the 
rehabilitated airports cannot be completely contained unless 
opium  cultivation  is  eradicated.  Fourth,  the  Government’s 
implementation capacity is weak, which may result in undue 
delays  in  implementing  key  activities.  Also  the  lack  of 
accounting and auditing capacity implies a risk of corruption. 
Thus resources will be allocated for consultancy services to 
assist with project management and implementation. Fifth, the 
PIU will consist of a team of consultants and MCAT staff and 
be headed by the deputy minister of MCAT. Because of the 
lack of capacity of MCAT staff, the consultant team will carry 
out  substantial  works  and  make  key  decisions.  Lack  of 
coordination between the project director and the consultant 
team  may  cause  delays  in  project  implementation.  ADB’s 
Resident  Mission  in  Afghanistan  will  play  a  key  role  in 
facilitating  close  coordination  to  prevent  any  stalemates  in 
implementation. Sixth, the progress of project implementation 
may be disrupted by poorly qualified MCAT staff assigned to 
the PIU. The consultant team will be involved in selecting staff 
to be assigned to the PIU and will provide continuous training 
for  them  once  they  have  been  selected  and  assigned. 
Seventh, the Procurement Unit of ARDS, a dedicated agency 
for  dealing  with  planning,  coordination,  preparation,  and 
procurement for major reconstruction projects, will handle all 
procurement  related  to  the  Project.  A  lack  of  close 
coordination between the PIU and the Procurement Unit of 
ARDS will cause delays in procurement.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Regional Airports Rehabilitation Project Phase 1.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
1.  Civil Aviation Infrastructure 
 
2.  Afghanistan is a landlocked country. Its population, estimated at 26 million, is spread 
over some 652,000 square kilometers of mostly mountainous terrain. Apart from Kabul, the 
capital, and a few provincial capitals such as Herat, Kandahar, and Mazar-e-Sharif, Afghanistan 
has few population centers. With the rugged Hindu Kush mountains occupying the geographical 
center of the country, the population centers are physically separated by steep mountains or by 
desert. In the absence of a railway system and functioning river ports, Afghanistan depends 
solely on road and air transport for the movement of passengers and goods. Since the end of 
the conflict, the country has made massive efforts to rehabilitate its 3,300-kilometer primary 
road network, which consists of a ring road that connects Kabul to major population centers and 
international  links  to  neighboring  countries.  While  the  road  network  will  offer  reliable  links 
capable  of  transporting  large  volumes  of  goods  and  people  when  rehabilitation  has  been 
completed, air transport will continue to offer the best, and often the only, quick link between 
remote  provinces  and  Kabul.  Because  of  its  strategic  geographic  location,  Afghanistan’s 
airspace offers one of the shortest routes between Asia and Europe, thus keeping Afghanistan’s 
airspace open to international overflights broadly benefits both the international community and 
the country. 
 
3.  Afghanistan has two major air gateways: Kabul International Airport serving the capital 
and Kandahar International Airport serving the south of the country. In the past, both airports 
were operated under instrument flight rules with day and night operations. Four major domestic 
airports (at Herat, Jalalabad, Kunduz, and Mazar-e-Sharif) provide air connections to the major 
cities. In addition, 16 regional domestic airports are spread across the country to serve smaller, 
more remote areas. These airports have mainly graveled airside facilities and operate under 
visual flight rules. 
 
4.  The prolonged conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in large-scale deterioration of the civil 
aviation infrastructure and depletion of skilled human resources. In addition to the lack of 
maintenance, the heavy damage inflicted during the decades of civil strife and the recent 
military  operations  accelerated  the  deterioration.  Paved  runways,  taxiways,  and  aprons, 
originally constructed to a high standard, are showing signs of severe ageing, embrittlement, 
and loss of bitumen, plus bomb craters and similar damage at a number of locations. Existing 
asphalt pavements will need asphalt overlays to restore proper longitudinal, cross–sectional, 
and  surface  texture.  Terminal  buildings  are in  poor  condition,  with few  amenities  such  as 
baggage handling facilities, restaurants, modern heating, lighting, toilets, or plumbing. Airport 
rescue and fire services are also in a poor state, with little equipment and limited mobility. 
Existing security arrangements are lax and trespassing by unauthorized persons and straying 
by animals onto airport property are common. Control tower operations and communications fall 
far short of minimum international standards. Organized, regular airport maintenance activities 
are currently nonexistent. Airport plans and surveys are not available and none of the airports

2      
has a master plan. The current state of civil aviation calls for a significant initiative to put the 
sector on par with international standards. The project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  Sector Management 
 
5.  The Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism (MCAT) is responsible for operating and 
maintaining the country’s 22 airports. MCAT also owns the national airline (Ariana Afghan 
Airlines)  and  major  hotels  and  is  responsible  for  promoting  tourism  and  providing  related 
services. MCAT is divided into eight presidencies, and currently has about 1,200 staff. Because 
of the deteriorated infrastructure and the depletion of trained staff, MCAT is unable to provide 
adequate  air  traffic  control  for  Afghanistan’s  airspace.  Given  existing  controllers;  technical 
support staff; and communications, surveillance, and navigation systems, assuring the safety of 
flights over Afghanistan is impossible. Immediate action has to be taken to rehabilitate and 
improve MCAT’s institutional capacity to operate and maintain the country’s airports. 
 
6.  The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  was  responsible  for  airport  design,  construction,  and 
maintenance. While MCAT currently continues to be responsible for airport management at all 
airports and air traffic control at certain large domestic airports, the role of the Ministry of Public 
Works has been defunct for many years. As a result, little airport maintenance work has been 
carried out since 1989. MCAT currently has no capability for carrying out either day-to-day or 
major periodic airport maintenance, but intends to take over the airport design, construction, and 
maintenance role in the future. 
 
7.  MCAT carries out regulatory functions on the basis of the Civil Aviation Act of July 2003. 
However, the act is seriously deficient in that it does not provide MCAT with the powers and 
authority to regulate civil aviation, such as the authority to issue the kinds of regulations, orders, 
and directives necessary to ensure the safety of aviation. The reestablishment of a regulatory 
system and of the capability to oversee safety is urgently needed to ensure the safety of air 
operations and the commercial success of Ariana Afghan Airlines. In the future, the regulatory 
framework will be based on a new civil aviation act that will enable the establishment of a civil 
aviation authority to act as a regulator instead of MCAT 
 
3.  Air Transport Services 
 
8.  Prior to 1989, air travel was a well-developed mode of transport in Afghanistan, popular 
with tourists and Afghan business people, Government officials, and other users who could 
afford to fly. The national airline, Ariana Afghan Airlines, was established in 1955 and has 
continued to operate, despite the adverse circumstances of the last two decades. At its peak in 
the late 1970s, Ariana’s fleet regularly flew to major Western European cities as well as to 
neighboring countries. During the last decade, however, Ariana lost most of its international 
routes mainly because of the conflict within the country and international sanctions imposed 
against the previous regime. It also lost most of its fleet and trained personnel.  
 
9.  Since the end of the conflict, Ariana has been expanding its international reach. It 
currently owns seven aircraft and operates international flights to 13 destinations to as far away 
as Germany. However, the old age of its fleet, the shortage of properly trained personnel, the 
poorly equipped maintenance facilities, and the lack of proper oversight functions in MCAT have 
contributed to concerns about the safety and reliability of Ariana’s fleet operations. In addition to 
Ariana, foreign airlines from nearby countries have started services to Afghanistan and Afghan 
airspace is rapidly opening up to international flights.

3   
10.  Ariana currently provides limited services on domestic routes. United Nations agencies 
and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) started a network of domestic services immediately 
following  the  commencement  of  international  assistance  to  Afghanistan  in  2002.  These 
services, operated by United Nations Humanitarian Air Services, the United Nations Assistance 
Mission to Afghanistan, and Partners in Aviation Communications and Technology chiefly cater 
to United Nations and NGO personnel. Kam Air, a start-up commercial airline licensed in 
November 2003, operates both international and domestic services and its domestic network 
currently serves six to eight airports. A large, untapped demand for air service appears to exist 
that can only be met by developing new commercial air services. Such development must be 
underpinned by the rehabilitation of airports and supporting infrastructure.  
 
11.  Appendix 2 presents an analysis of the civil aviation sector in Afghanistan.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Transport Sector Review  
 
12.  The  Transport  Sector  Review  (TSR),  prepared  with  assistance  from  the  Swedish 
International  Development  Cooperation  Agency  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), 
comprehensively  assessed  the  entire  transport  sector  in  Afghanistan  and  made  policy

objectives are to facilitate economic development by improving access to markets and reducing 
poverty and promoting national and regional integration, development, and security. In the civil 
aviation sector, the Government’s goal is to rehabilitate and improve airports and air transport, 
together with tourism services. This will bring remote areas into the mainstream economy and 
permit improved linkages with and faster travel to and from the rest of the world and within the 
country between major cities and towns. It will also facilitate the movement of people, including 
tourists, for whom Afghanistan’s natural and historical sites should become an increasingly 
attractive destination, and increase trade in low-volume, high-value goods. On this basis, the

4.  ADB Strategy 
 
19.  ADB’s Initial Country Strategy and Program for Afghanistan (2002–2004) identified the 
following four principles for ADB’s medium-term development framework. First, Afghan men and 
women must be fully involved in all stages of the reconstruction process from planning to design 
and implementation and the Government must fully own and drive the reconstruction process. 
The  social  exclusion  of  Afghan  women,  in  particular,  should  end  with  their  return  to  the 
socioeconomic mainstream. Second, an appropriate policy and institutional framework must be 
in  place  to  support  investment  in  reconstruction,  which  also  requires  sound  governance. 
Transparency,  accountability,  participation,  and  the  rule  of  law  provide  the  basis  of  good 
governance, which must be established at all levels from the central level to community and 
local  levels.  Third,  substantial  institutional  capacity  building  is  needed  to  ensure  the 
effectiveness of the reconstruction and development process. This will require solid partnerships 
with other aid agencies, NGOs, and community-based organizations. Fourth, investments in 
reconstruction must promote human rights and social inclusion and respond to the needs of 
returning refugees, internally displaced people, and the vulnerable and disabled.  
 
20.  In relation to the rehabilitation of physical infrastructure, the Initial Country Strategy and 
Program  emphasized  that  physical  infrastructure  constraints,  which  arose  because  of  the 
inhospitable environment, hostilities, and disrepair of facilities, should be removed to revive 
normal economic activities. The Initial Country Strategy and Program identified those physical 
constraints requiring priority attention as (i) agricultural land and irrigation facilities inaccessible 
because of mines and unexploded ordnance or irrigation systems in disrepair; (ii) economic and 
social infrastructure destroyed or degraded; and (iii) other infrastructure destroyed, degraded, or 
inadequately exploited. Infrastructure rehabilitation, reconstruction, and development and mine 
clearing are to address these constraints.  
 
21.  With this strategy in place, the Country Strategy and Program Update for Afghanistan 
(2003–2005) indicated that ADB assistance in the civil aviation sector would be directed toward 
the rehabilitation of important regional airports to promote the integration of remote regions and 
facilitate  more  rapid  economic  growth  in  those  areas.  The  Country  Strategy  and  Program

and Kandahar airports. It also includes TA for institutional strengthening of MCAT in 2005 in the

6.  Security Situation 
 
28.  Security  is  the  main  issue  and  constraint  in  relation  to  reconstruction.  Without  an 
adequate level of security, the country will fail to achieve key national goals for economic 
growth, political normalization and national reconciliation, and social development. Afghanistan 
has made significant gains in security in the last 2 years that have laid a solid foundation for 
continued and accelerated reform and has avoided a resurgence of major civil conflict. Sporadic 
outbreaks  of  armed  conflict,  even  if  not  always  fully  resolved,  have  been  contained  and 
prevented  from  spreading.  The  internationally  sponsored  security  arrangements  for  Kabul, 
based  on  the  international  security  assistance  forces  working  in  cooperation  with  Afghan 
security forces, have worked reasonably well. Some improvements have been made in the 
police force, and the first units of a national army have been formed and trained. Security on the 
main intercity roads has improved significantly compared with the situation 2 years ago.  
 
29.  Nevertheless, the security situation has deteriorated in parts of the country, particularly 
in rural areas. Opium poppy cultivation, which had been sharply reduced during 2000, and 
especially in 2001, made a strong comeback in 2002, and cultivation expanded further during 
the 2003 season. Narcotics production and trade and the profits from these activities constitute 
a major threat to Afghanistan’s security, political normalization, and economic development. 
Containment and eradication of illicit drug production will inevitably be a long-term effort that 
requires a combination of effective law enforcement and rural development that generates 
alternative livelihoods. 
 
30.  The disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration program to reduce the number and 
size  of  private  militias  and  undercut  the  military  strength  of  the  regional  governors  has 
progressed  slowly.  A  number  of  local  militias  have  resisted,  claiming  that  the  Ministry  of 
Defense was monopolized by a particular ethnic group. Even though the Government replaced 
a number of senior ministry officials belonging to this ethnic group with officials belonging to 
other ethnic groups in September 2003, some concerns linger about the loyalty of lower-ranking 
ministry officials. This situation enables regional warlords to maintain their military strength and 
continue to influence regional politics, which has not helped the security situation. The security 
situation will continue to constrain the progress of reconstruction, and concerns about security 
may continue to discourage foreign and large-scale domestic investment. 
 
31.  This fragile security situation will adversely affect the implementation of the Project 
because (i) the security hazard around project locations will disrupt and delay construction work; 
(ii) the supply of raw materials, which will have to be transported through areas controlled by 
regional  warlords,  may  be  hampered;  and  (iii)  the  supervision  of  construction  work  by 
consultants and ADB staff may be constrained. To overcome these problems, the Project will 
make use of the arrangements devised by ADB’s TA for the Security of ADB-Financed Project 
in Afghanistan,3 which will help provide a safe work environment for on-site personnel assigned

7.  Opium-Related Problems 
 
32.  Afghanistan is the world’s largest producer of illicit opium. The current ban on cultivation 
has had an extremely limited effect, and opium is a major source of cash income for farmers 
because of its ready profitability and because of a lack of other livelihood alternatives. According 
to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), opium was cultivated on 80,000 
hectares  in 2003, an increase of 8% over 2002, and production increased by 6% to 3,968 tons, 
20 times more than in 2001, the last year of Taliban rule. Farmers grew poppies in 28 of the 
country’s 32 provinces in 2003, up from 18 in 1999. UNODC estimates that 264,000 families, or 
about 7% of Afghanistan’s population, are producing poppies, each cultivating an average of 0.3 
hectares. UNODC estimates average yearly earnings at $3,900 per opium-growing family, or 
$594 per capita, in a country where per capita gross domestic product is only $207. The share 
of poppy production in the economy is large. If opium exports were included, total exports would 
be 40% greater.  
 
33.  Poppy  cultivation  and  narcotics  production  and  trade  constitute  a  major  threat  to 
Afghanistan’s security and political normalization and tie a poor rural population to regional 
warlords and international crime syndicates. To combat this problem, the Government has 
developed a national counternarcotics strategy and is working with aid agencies involved in the 
security  sector  on  containing  and  eradicating  poppy  cultivation  and  providing  support  for 
alternative livelihoods. ADB support focuses on helping farm households develop livelihood 
alternatives to poppy cultivation. ADB activities in this regard include creating an enabling 
environment  for  the  commercialization  and  diversification  of  agricultural  production  and 
rehabilitating irrigation systems, which ADB is pursuing through a demand-driven, participatory, 
and  community-based  approach.  ADB  is  also  supporting  measures  to  contain  the  flow  of 
narcotics across borders through some of its subregional activities, including building capacity 
and strengthening customs and immigration departments in the region.  
 
8.  Lessons Learned 
 
34.  A number of lessons can be drawn from past emergency assistance projects, best 
practices, and ADB’s initial lending and nonlending operations in Afghanistan since 2002. First, 
continued emphasis has to be given to capacity building to improve planning, project design and 
implementation, administration, and financial management. Second, aid coordination by means 
of consultative groups is important for avoiding duplication and delays. Third, aid groups must 
work closely with a country’s MOF and central bank to develop a viable and working payment 
system,  without  which  maintaining  a  flow  of  funds  is  difficult.  Fourth,  capacity  building  in 
executing  agencies  is vital,  and  consulting  services  for  project  design  and  implementation 
should provide for the training of executing agency staff in the operations and maintenance of 
rehabilitated facilities. Fifth, the number of procurement packages should be minimized, given 
the limited implementation capacity of executing agencies. Sixth, ADB’s procurement guidelines 
should be applied flexibly for emergency assistance projects to allow reduced procurement 
periods  for  the  urgent  delivery  of  project  components.  Seventh,  law  and  order  situations 
resulting from conflict hamper the smooth implementation of projects and extensive security 
plans should be put in place to address possible security hazards in project locations. All these 
lessons have been incorporated into the design of the Project.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Financial Management and Financial Viability 
 
61.  Except for military airports, MCAT directly owns, manages, and operates all airports and 
air navigation services. All revenues generated by civil airports and air navigation services are 
collected  by  the  civil  aviation  authorities  under  MCAT  and  deposited  in  the  Government 
treasury. All expenditure on salaries, repairs and maintenance, and utilities are met by the 
Government’s budget allocation. Accounting for the revenues and expenses of MCAT and the 
airports  and  air  navigation  services  is  centralized  in  MOF.  MOF  finalizes  the  operational 
expenditure budget on the basis of proposals prepared by MCAT. After MOF finalizes the 
details of the annual expenditure budget, MCAT transfers the budget provision to each airport.  
 
62.  Financial projections have been prepared for Afghanistan’s civil aviation sector to assess 
the Project’s financial viability and sustainability as a whole (Appendix 9). The projections 
indicate that financial revenues will be sufficient to cover operating and maintenance costs.  
 
63.  The financial evaluation for each airport was undertaken in real terms using constant 
2004 prices. Incremental costs and benefits were derived by evaluating the financial position of 
each airport under with and without project scenarios. The financial internal rate of return for the

1 5   
seven airports, computed on an after tax basis, ranges from 3.7% to 7.9%, with an average over 
all seven subprojects of 5%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital, 
also computed on an after tax basis, of 4%. Sensitivity and risk analyses indicates that the 
financial internal rate of return for all airports is robust under adverse conditions. Based on the 
financial projections and financial evaluation, the Project is considered both financially viable 
and sustainable. 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
 
64.  For the economic evaluation, the benefits of the Project have been calculated in term of 
users’ willingness to pay as reflected in incremental revenues from airport operations, such as 
landing charges, passenger service charges, and other fees and charges for airport services. 
The evaluation also includes as assessment of (i)  benefits to operators, such as savings in 
direct wear and tear costs and fuel; (ii) benefits to passengers, such as direct time savings; (iii) 
benefits from safety improvements; and (iv) benefits to regional and local communities from 
such things as the development of tourism.  
 
65.  The benefits to operators are substantial in terms of improvements in aircraft productivity 
resulting from reduced downtimes for maintenance; elimination of costs associated with damage 
to aircraft (external instruments, wing flaps, propeller blades, engines) caused by  flying stones 
from gravel runways; and reduced costs for tire replacement by extending the operational life of 
tires. Aircraft landing on a gravel surface take longer to stop than on a bitumen surface because 
of reduced braking efficiency, thus bitumen runways improve fuel efficiency. The Project will 
also severely diminish the risk and economic costs of accidents or other incidents caused by 
airstrip incursions, which are increasingly becoming a safety hazard because of poor airstrip 
conditions and poor visibility. 
 
66.  The Project’s economic costs include the resource costs for traded and nontraded costs, 
materials,  and  labor.  All  cost  elements  are  valued  at  border  prices,  using  a  world  price 
numeraire, with all taxes and duties excluded. A standard conversion factor of 0.80 was applied 
to the financial costs of nontraded inputs to calculate economic prices. Subproject facilities are 
expected to have an average economic life of 30 years. 
 
67.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the seven airports ranges from 18.0% to 
28.4%, with a consolidated EIRR of 22.2%. A sensitivity analysis tested the effects of possible 
unfavorable scenarios resulting from changes in the key parameters that determine the Project’s 
costs and benefits. This analysis indicates that the Project’s economic viability would remain 
satisfactory even under adverse scenarios, and that it would require a cost increase i of 113% 
or a decrease in benefits of 53% to reach a cut-off EIRR of 12%. Appendix 10 presents details 
of  the  economic  analysis.  The  project  benefits  distribution  analysis  is  in  Supplementary 
Appendix C. 
 
C.  Social Impacts 
 
1.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
 
68.  The Project’s impact on land and resettlement will be insignificant, because most of the 
rehabilitation activities are to be carried out on land the Government already owns. Of the seven 
airports included in phase I, the Project will have land acquisition and resettlement impacts at 
only  four  airports  (Bamyan,  Faizabad,  Qalai-Naw,  and  Zaranj).  The  Project  will  affect  42 
permanent residential structures, as a result of which nearly 2 hectares of homestead land will

16      
also have to be acquired. In addition, 0.8 hectare of agricultural land owned by the Agriculture 
Department and currently being used by a private agency for agricultural research will have to 
be transferred to MCAT. Two community structures, including one graveyard and one mosque, 
will be affected, and five households currently cultivating Government land would suffer income 
losses. Overall, the Project will affect 56 households and 196 people. Those people affected will 
receive the replacement value of their property and other physical assets and assistance to 
cover income losses and relocation and additional assistance will also be provided to vulnerable 
households. The estimated cost of land acquisition and resettlement is AF7,853,023 or $0.17 
million. The short resettlement plan has been translated into Dari and will be disclosed to those 
affected (Appendix 11). The complete plan will be publicly available at MCAT, ADB’s Resident 
Mission in Afghanistan, and ADB’s web site.  
 
2.  Indigenous People 
 
69.  Afghanistan is home to many ethnic and linguistic groups, as well as to several sects of 
Islam and to other religions. Historic and geographic factors have created and preserved this 
diversity, although the degree of cultural assimilation varies and a considerable degree of 
cultural homogeneity exists. The main ethnic groups in the project area are Pushtuns, Tajik, 
Hazara,  Turkoman,  Uzbek,  and  other  Muslim  and  non-Muslim  groups.  These  ethnic 
communities have become part of mainstream society and are prominent groups with large 
populations  in  each  region.  The  social  assessment  did  not  identify  the  presence  of  any 
indigenous populations in the project area. None of the ethnic communities will be marginalized 
because of a dominant community in the region or by project development. The summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12. 
 
D.  Poverty Reduction Impacts 
 
70.  Approximately 53% of Afghanistan’s population is classified as poor, that is, living on 
less than $1 per day or approximately 2,100 kilocalories per day. In the project provinces, the 
average daily income is less than $1, no more than $0.74 per person per day, compared with a 
national average income for unskilled labor of $1.7 to $3.2 per person per day. The social 
assessment in the project area also revealed that 50% to 60% of the population lives below the 
poverty line and has an average income of AF2,000 to AF3,000 per month. Thus high levels of 
poverty are apparent in all the project provinces.  
 
71.  The direct benefit of the Project to poor households will be employment in construction 
activities at airports in terms of net income earned during the project period. Both poor and 
nonpoor households are likely to benefit directly in the medium and long term, as additional jobs 
will be created in airport administration and management, fire fighting services, and catering; 
with  private  airlines;  with  local  contractor  firms  likely  to  be  involved  in  maintaining  airport 
facilities; and, most important, in the tourism industry. An indirect but important impact will be 
the provision of much needed humanitarian aid and basic public services to remote regions. The 
Project will also generate additional employment opportunities by facilitating access to regional 
and international markets for agricultural, livestock, and other manufactured and perishable 
products; facilitating regional trade; and stimulating the growth of local trade and enterprises.  
 
E.  Environmental Impacts 
 
72.  The  Project  is  categorized  as  “B”  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  2003  Environmental 
Assessment Guidelines. Therefore an initial environmental examination (IEE) was undertaken 
as part of the feasibility study. The IEE found that the Project would not have any significant

1 7   
impact that would need to be assessed further. The most likely environmental impact is related 
to the construction work, such as erosion and sedimentation associated with earthworks. Other 
impacts are increased dust and volatile gases from hot mix plants used for the reconstruction of 
runways and taxiways and the contamination of surface water. All these impacts are temporary 
and mitigation measures are manageable. Mitigation measures during the construction stage 
will be incorporated into contractors’ job assignments, therefore the IEE report will have been 
made available to contractors. The environmental impacts related with actual airport operations 
are (i) noise caused by increased air traffic; (ii) solid wastes and wastewater resulting from office 
and  airport  activities;  and  (iii)  oil  wastes  from  the  operation  of  power  generation,  aircraft 
cleaning, and refueling activities. However, given the level of airport operations, these impacts 
will not be significant. Nonetheless, proper waste management and the installation of oil traps in 
all outlets and drainage facilities prior to discharging wastewater into water bodies will be 
necessary. The summary IEE is in Appendix 13.  
 
F.  Risks 
 
73.  Implementation of the Project entails a number of risks as follows: 
 
(i)  The overall political and security situation remains volatile. ADB will need to 
monitor the situation closely and coordinate with local and central authorities and 
the United Nations to ensure that ADB operations are adequately protected.7 
ADB’s TA for the Security of ADB-Financed Projects in Afghanistan will provide 
advice on how to ensure a safe work environment for on-site personnel assigned 
by  the  contractors,  subcontractors,  and  consulting  firms.  Under  prevailing 
conditions, however, the security risk cannot be mitigated completely, and delays 
in project implementation will be inevitable if security hazards occur in project 
locations despite the measures put in place to control the risk. 
(ii)  The regional warlords have maintained their military strength and their influence 
in regional politics. This political instability could hamper a smooth supply of raw 
materials and equipment, which would be transported through areas controlled 
by regional warlords, and constrain the supervision of construction works by 
consultants and ADB staff.  
(iii)  The rehabilitated regional airports could be used to transport opium. The security 
checks carried out in regional airports will be strengthened, but the distribution of 
opium  through  rehabilitated  airports  cannot  be  completely  contained  unless 
opium cultivation is eradicated.  
(iv)  The implementation of key activities may be unduly delayed because of the 
Government’s weak implementation capacity. Also the lack of accounting and 
auditing capacity implies a risk of corruption. Resources will be allocated for 
consultancy services to help with project management and implementation. 
(v)  The PIU will consist of a team of consultants and MCAT staff with the deputy 
minister of MCATserving as project director. Because of the lack of capacity of 
MCAT staff, the consultant team will be responsible for a significant amount of 
the work and take key decisions, and any lack of coordination between the 
project  director  and  the  consultant  team  may  delay  project  implementation. 
ADB’s  Resident  Mission  will  play  a  key  role  in  facilitating  coordination  and 
prevent any stalemate in implementation.

communities and foreign tourists. Passenger and freight data for 1980 indicate that upward of 
125,000 passengers traveled between 12 airports. However, after 20 years of conflict, most of 
the sector’s infrastructure has either been damaged or destroyed, airlines have been decimated, 
and trained human resources have been severely depleted. Since 2002, limited civil aviation 
has given crucial support to emergency rehabilitation and recovery efforts, and the nation 
building  processes  currently  under  way  will  be  highly  dependent  on  civil  aviation  for  the 
foreseeable future. 
 
3.  The  national  road  system,  which  is  currently  in  poor  condition,  is  undergoing  an 
extensive rehabilitation program, with completion of the ring road as the first priority. While this 
will restore relatively rapid and reliable services for freight and passengers within proximity of 
the ring road, many other more isolated provincial centers with large populations will have to 
wait many years for good road connections. Many roads may never be upgraded to highway 
standards because of constraints imposed by the terrain. 
 
4.  Airports and air transport present different challenges for policymakers and regulators. 
The differences arise from the cost characteristics and from the market structures through which 
each transportation subsector provides facilities and services. Afghanistan’s airport industry is 
undergoing a transformation from being a grossly undermanaged public utility in decline with 
mounting financial losses, a result of the prolonged conflict situation, to being a more efficient, 
market-oriented industry with a more commercial outlook.  
 
5.  Changes in Afghanistan’s political and economic growth prospects have created a new 
challenge, namely, establishing an appropriate form of competition and rebuilding regulatory 
institutions to improve efficiency and effectiveness in the delivery of domestic and international 
aviation services. 
 
6.  The  Government  is  currently  addressing  the  aviation  sector’s  rehabilitation  and 
development needs required to support the rebound with financial and technical assistance from 
external  funding  agencies.  If  the  current  trend  in  development  is  to  be  sustainable,  the 
Government needs to remove as many as possible of the impediments that tend to suppress 
business and consumer confidence. 
 
B.  Institutional Organization and Responsibilities 
 
7.  Prior to 1989, the Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism (MCAT) was responsible for 
airport operations and generally provided an airport manager and air traffic control staff for each 
airport. The Ministry of Public Works (MOPW) was responsible for airport design, construction, 
and maintenance. While MCAT is currently continuing with airport management at all airports 
and air traffic control at certain of the larger domestic airports, MOPW has not played a role in 
airports for many years. As a result, little airport maintenance work has been carried out since

24   Appendix 2 
1989. MCAT currently has no capability to carry out either day-to-day or major, periodic airport 
maintenance, but does intend to take over airport design, construction, and maintenance in the 
future. 
 
C.  Airport Infrastructure and Supporting Services 
 
1.  Infrastructure 
 
8.  Published  information  indicates  that  Afghanistan  had  47  airports  in  2002,  including 
seasonal landing strips in remote border areas, or roughly 1.63 airports per 1 million people. Of 
these 47 airports, 10 were reported to have paved runways (with 3 of these located above 3,047 
meters), while the remaining 37 have gravel runways. The country also has five heliports 
serving military and humanitarian needs. However, the United Nations Joint Logistics Center 
only recognizes 27 airports, of which only the following 13 receive commercial flights: 
 
(i)  international (category I): Kabul, Kandahar; 
(ii)  major domestic (category II): Herat, Kunduz, Jalalabad, Mazar-e-Sharif; 
(iii)  regional  (category  III):  Bamyan,  Chaghcharan,  Faizabad,  Farah,  Maimana, 
Taloqan; and 
(iv)  subregional (category IV): Zaranj. 
 
9.  Because of the restructuring of MCAT and a reduction in the agency’s personnel and 
financial  resources,  regional  airstrips  are  not  being  maintained  and  are  being  allowed  to 
deteriorate. This situation has serious implications for aircraft passenger and crew safety and for 
the cost of operations.  
 
10.  The Government has prepared a civil aviation and airport development plan, which is in 
line with International Civil Aviation Organization standards and recommendations and reflects 
the priorities and strategy of MCAT. The plans includes 
(i)  upgrading Kabul International Airport to full international standards, including the 
terminal building, facilities, and amenities, at a cost of approximately $100 million 
over 7 years; 
(ii)  upgrading the international terminals at Herat, Jalalabad, and Mazar-e-Sharif at 
an estimated cost of $50 million over 7 years; 
(iii)  rehabilitating the two major domestic airports at Kunduz and Faizabad at an 
estimated cost of $10 million each over 7 years; and 
(iv)  rehabilitating the remaining 13 domestic airports in two phases at an estimated 
cost of $5 million for each airport.  
 
11.  The total cost of the plan is estimated at $375 million and is to be apportioned as follows: 
runways, 30%; terminals and required facilities, 20%; vehicles and equipment, 20%; air traffic 
control, 15%; approach roads and parking, 10%; and aviation safety, 5%. 
 
12.  The  aim  is  for  all  airports  to  be able  to  handle  more  landings,  thereby  generating 
substantial revenue for the Government, improving linkages, and allowing for faster travel to and 
from the rest of the world and between regional centers, which will increase tourist penetration. 
 
2.  Air Navigation Services 
 
13.  All navigation, communication, landing aid, and meteorological facilities were destroyed 
during the conflict. NATO currently provides air traffic control services at Kabul International

Airport. Only daytime flights are accepted for regional services. At present, no facilities for air 
traffic management exist at the major domestic and regional airports. There is also an acute 
shortage of qualified and trained air traffic controllers and maintenance personnel. 
 
14.  Currently, MCAT levies a $400 charge on all international and inter-regional airline flights 
overflying the country even though minimal information is provided to air crews. 
 
 
3.  Meteorological Services 
 
15.  Meteorological services at Kabul and all other regional and domestic services are out of 
service until International Security Assistance Force, and then NATO, install their own services. 
There is an urgent need to install and train specialists in the operation of automatic weather 
observation systems at the two international airports (Kabul and Kandahar) and the four main 
domestic airports (Herat, Kunduz, Jalalabad, and Mazar-I-Sharif). 
 
4.  Safety Oversight 
 
16.  The civil aviation safety orders of 1972 do not provide MCAT with clear power and 
authority to regulate civil aviation, and therefore the authority to issue regulations, orders, and 
directives necessary to ensure the safety of aviation, i.e., those pertaining to security, accident 
and incident reporting, certification of airports, licensing of air traffic controllers, and certification 
of air operators. The authority over these areas is not institutionalized in the organization, which 
can seriously hinder the sector’s development. 
 
17.  Airport  incursion  is  becoming  a  serious  problem  at  many  airstrips  and  is  likely  to 
continue. Airstrips are used for many community activities, but are primarily used as a means of 
access, especially where local footpaths and vehicle tracks cross runways or run alongside 
them. This is a matter that needs to be addressed to reduce the probability of accidents that 
could be catastrophic for crews, passengers, and local bystanders. 
 
5.  Human Resources 
 
18.  Aviation in Afghanistan faces serious human resource challenges because of the lack of 
skilled  manpower.  To  be  sustainable  in  a  deregulated  market,  MCAT  and  other  aviation 
agencies will need to recruit and train suitable personnel if investment over the next 7 years is to 
be  sustainable.  Like  in  many  other  developing  countries,  the  maintenance  and  upkeep  of 
infrastructure and services is essential for supporting on-going improvements in efficiency and 
lowering utilization costs. 
 
19.  When new infrastructure comes on-stream starting at the end of 2005, properly staffing 
the  airports  with  personnel  trained  in  airport  management,  operations,  maintenance,  fire 
fighting,  and  so  on  will  be  essential.  Hence  the  intensive  training  program  that  is  being 
undertaken as part of the Project. 
 
D.  Domestic Civil Aviation 
 
1.  Market 
 
20.  At this early stage in the development of the postwar, domestic aviation sector, the 
market served is predominantly humanitarian, but with a growing commercial sector. This is not

infrastructure has deteriorated to such an extent that a journey by road—often the preferred 
choice of nongovernment organizations (NGOs)—is long and arduous; safety and security are 
still major concerns, with many areas of the country still classified as serious security risk areas; 
and facilities available to travelers are basic or nonexistent. 
 
21.  The domestic aviation sector serves and supports the high-value, time-sensitive end of 
the transport market. In 2000, up to 3,400 departures were recorded. During this early stage of 
postwar reconstruction, the market as a whole is characterized by widely varying load factors,

2.  Operators 
 
23.  Prior to 1989, air travel was a well-developed mode of transport in Afghanistan, popular 
with tourists, Afghan business people, government officials, and other users with the money to 
fly. Two airlines served an extensive domestic network that gave access to the main cities of 
most provinces and to a number of smaller, isolated communities. 
 
24.  Because of the destruction of airport, navigation aid, and air traffic control infrastructure 
in the years of conflict, domestic air services are currently rudimentary. The state airline, Ariana 
Afghan Airlines, is still recovering from severe losses of equipment and skilled personnel, but 
provides limited domestic services from Kabul to Herat, Jalalabad, Kandahar, and Mazar-e-
Sharif. The Boeing B727 aircraft used by Ariana are expensive to operate, their technology is 
old, and they are too big for domestic services. 
 
25.  United Nations agencies and NGOs started a network of domestic services immediately 
following  the  commencement  of  international  assistance  to  Afghanistan  in  2002.  These 
services, operated by United Nations Humanitarian Air Services (UNHAS), the United Nations 
Assistance Mission to Afghanistan (UNAMA), and Partners in Aviation Communications and 
Technology (PacTec), use small aircraft with 8 to 18 seats and chiefly cater to United Nations 
and NGO personnel. UNHAS will continue this support role even when commercial services 
become more widespread. UNHAS also operates a DC9 between Kabul and Dubai, Dushanbe,

Herat, Islamabad, and Kandahar, while UNAMA has one or two An72 mixed configuration 
cargo/passenger aircraft mainly for domestic use. 
 
26.  Kam Air, a start-up airline that began operations in November 2003, is operating both 
international and domestic services. Its domestic network currently serves six or eight airports 
using 50-seat An24 aircraft. Indications already suggest that a large, untapped demand for air 
services exists, which can only be met by developing new commercial air services. Such 
development must be underpinned by the rehabilitation of airports and supporting infrastructure. 
 
27.  A  number  of  corporate  charter  aircraft  also  operate  within  Afghanistan  and  nearby 
countries. These are all small turboprops similar to the Beechcraft 200 and 1900s operated by 
UNHAS, UNAMA, and PacTec. Many large cargo aircraft fly into Kabul and Kandahar on both 
civil  and  military  missions,  but  few  are  deployed  to  other  domestic airports.  Nevertheless, 
military C130 cargo aircraft regularly fly to some airports, including Bamyan. 
 
E.  Opportunities for Improving Airport Efficiency 
 
28.  As in all industrial and many developing economies, air travel will continue to play an 
essential role in Afghanistan. It can provide a safe, fast, comfortable, and convenient connection 
between the capital, Kabul, and other centers of commerce, administration, and tourism. As 
such, it can appeal to business people, government officials, international and domestic tourists, 
and  to  citizens  who  have  the  means  to  travel  for  personal  reasons.  Air  cargo  is  also  an 
important  factor,  enabling  the  delivery  of  urgent  supplies  and  exports  of  high–value,  low–
volume, manufactured or perishable products. Air also provides rapid access for humanitarian 
aid to areas that might be devastated by natural disasters, famine, epidemics, and the like and 
for the evacuation of the sick and injured. When the country returns to relative stability and the 
normal processes of nation building commence, unfettered by security concerns and uncertainty 
about the future, civil aviation will become even more important to the national economy.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  Prior to 1989, air travel was a well-developed transport mode in Afghanistan, popular 
with tourists and Afghan business people, government officials, and others. Two airlines served 
an extensive domestic network that provided access to the main cities of most provinces and a 
number of smaller, isolated communities. Because of the destruction of airport, navigational aid, 
and  air  traffic  control  infrastructure  in  the  years  of  conflict,  domestic  air  services  are 
rudimentary. Currently the condition of regional airports is such that it only allows for restricted 
operations, and these are often curtailed by poor airstrip condition, poor visibility, and the 
absence of adequate terminal conditions and security. 
 
2.  The Project will help Afghanistan address its domestic needs for aviation development. 
During phase I of the Project, rehabilitation work will be carried at seven regional airports: 
Bamyan,  Chaghcharan,  Farah,  Faizabad,  Maimana,  Qalai-Naw,  and  Zaranj.  The  proposed 
upgrading and improvement works will include the following:  
 
(i)  level 1: constructing perimeter fences to improve airstrip safety and the efficiency 
of air service operators;  
(ii)  level 2: reducing the substantial cost of aircraft maintenance and repairs by 
upgrading gravel pavement to asphalt standard; and 
(iii)  level 3: constructing adequate terminal and airport operation facilities, including 
control towers. 
 
3.  The main objective of the Project is to enhance civil aviation infrastructure to support 
reliable and safe operations in compliance with International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) 
standards across all major and minor airports in the country. Bringing these airports up to 
standard will (i) remove infrastructure constraints on the growth of domestic air services; (ii) 
reduce  airlines’  operational  costs;  (iii)  improve  air  safety;  (iv)  assist  the  development  of 
commercial,  agricultural,  and  tourism  activities  in  the  Project  areas  and  improve  market 
connections; (v) facilitate the provision of much needed humanitarian aid and basic public 
services  to  remote  regions;  and  (vi)  improve  the  access  of  local  communities  to  social 
services—medical, educational, and administrative—and to better job opportunities.

11.  The benefits to operators are substantial in terms of improvements to aircraft productivity 
from reduced maintenance downtime; elimination of costs associated with damage to aircraft 
caused by flying stones from gravel runways (external instruments, wing flaps, propeller blades, 
engines); and reduced cost of tire replacement by extending the operational life of tires. Gravel 
runways have lower coefficients of friction than bitumen runways, meaning that aircraft landing 
on a gravel surface take longer to stop because of reduced braking efficiency, thus bitumen 
runways improve fuel efficiency. The Project will also severely diminish the risk (and economic 
costs) of accidents and other incidents caused by airstrip incursions, which are increasingly 
becoming a safety hazard because of poor regional airstrip conditions and poor visibility.

time (valued in terms of the economic value of time) and on diminished risk of flight cancellation 
or diversion, and safety improvements calculated on the basis of risk reduction of a catastrophic 
accident.1 The confidence of travelers is currently significantly affected by uncontrolled airstrips, 
poor visibility, and a poor record of on time arrivals and departures..

airport construction and operation, the economy could enjoy significant secound-round benefits

more  potential  for  attracting  tourists  than  others.  Consequently,  a  forecast  based  on

percent of tourism expenditure represents the real cost of consumption of locally produced 
goods and services and return on local investments. On this basis, it is estimated that about 
$110 per tourist represents the real net benefit from tourists arriving by air. The long-term 
benefits to the community are conservative, because they would also include the benefits from 
additional jobs that would not be created if the airports had not been upgraded.

Phase I of the project will cover seven regional airports in the provinces of Badakhshan, Bagdis, Bamyan, Farah, Faryab,

affected people’s livelihoods. The decline in farm productivity and the loss of seasonal opportunities for agricultural labor is

18.  The total estimated cost of implementing the environmental monitoring plan has been 
calculated as $0.28 million. The proposed monitoring plan includes monitoring the water quality 
of  drainage  from  project  areas  with  a  focus  on  BOD  (Biological  Oxygen  Demand)    COD 
(Chemical Oxygen Demand),  oil and grease, TSS (Total Suspended Solid) and air quality (SPM 
(Suspended  Particulate  Matter),  PAHs  (Polycyclic  Aromatic  Hydrocarbons),  NOx  (Nitrogen 
Oxide), SO2 (Sulphur Dioxide)  prior to starting the work; monitoring the implementation of 
mitigation measures and water and air quality during the construction period and water and air 
quality; and continued monitoring of air and water quality and noise levels following project 
completion.   
 
F.   Public Consultation and Disclosure 
 
19.  During project preparation, five levels of consultations were undertaken using a public 
information consultation tool. The first level was in Kabul at the national capital level with various 
funding  agencies,  research  agencies,  relevant  international  and  local  nongovernment 
organizations, and relevant ministries and Government departments. The second level was at 
the  provincial  level  with  provincial  heads,  local  administrations,  municipalities,  agriculture 
departments,  legal  departments,  airport  authorities,  cadastral  departments,  and  relevant 
international  and  local  nongovernment  organizations.  The  third  level  was  with  community 
leaders  and  local  educated  people  primarily  to  solicit  information  about  natural  resources, 
community  facilities,  and  likely  impacts  of  the  Project.  The  fourth  level  was  with  affected 
communities. The fifth level included consultation with people potentially affected by the Project, 
including  women  members  of  affected  families  on  an  individual  level.  Prior  to  these 
consultations, relevant information, such as a description of the Project and its objectives and 
an explanation of possible adverse effects of the proposed Project, were disseminated in a form 
and language meaningful to the groups consulted. 
 
20.  Major  perceived  benefits  as  identified  during  the  community  consultations  were  (i) 
reduced travel time; (ii) better access to public amenities; (iii) significant economic opportunities 
resulting from increased access to markets; (iv) benefits to local businesses from increased air 
traffic; and (v) increased regional development in terms of industry, tourism, and development of 
crafts industries. The major perceived losses include (i) loss of residential and agricultural 
properties; (ii) safety risks posed by increased numbers of aircraft; (iv) children’s loss of playing 
areas following the fencing of airports; and (v) increased noise pollution. The results from the 
community consultation were taken into account during project planning and were incorporated 
into the preparation of the resettlement plan as well as the preparation of mitigation measures.  
 
G.   Findings and Recommendations 
 
21.  The  initial  findings  of  the  IEE  study  show  that  the  negative  environmental  impacts 
associated with the rehabilitation of the regional airports are deemed to be minor and the 
mitigation measures will be incorporated into the contract document for the contractors. All the 
proposed  mitigation  measures  for  all  project  components  are  manageable,  and  a  full 
environmental impact assessment to assess further impacts of the Project is not required. 
 
H.   Conclusion 
 
                                                                                                                                                                                 
22.  The Project is classified as an environmental category “B” project, as it is unlikely to 
have  any  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts.  The  Project  will  generate  social  and 
environmental  benefits,  particularly  in  terms  of  enhancing  the  environmental  and  safety

performance of improved runways, alleviating dust at the airports, providing water and sanitation 
facilities at the airports, and providing warning system and aviation aids. Implementation of the 
proposed Project will provide the country with facilities that could adequately accommodate 
about 10,000 passengers annually by the end of the first 10 years and is expected to increase 
the tourism potential of the country. Direct employment opportunities that will be generated from 
the proposed Project are estimated to be 1,000 people during construction and 50 people during 
operations. In addition, several indirect benefits will accrue to users, the business community, 
the poor, aircraft operators, and suppliers of various goods and services. The Project will 
especially benefit women through the provision of an improved, secure, and efficient mode of 
transportation in comparison with road transportation. Nonetheless, the residents of nearby 
settlements will be subjected to both temporary and permanent marginal increases in noise 
levels, which in terms of level, time of occurrence, and distribution will not be significant.
